items.description: Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.message: River levels have risen on the Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk due to recent rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast today Wednesday 5/10/22. We expect river levels to rise further but then peak in the early afternoon, falling slowly overnight into Thursday. Areas most at risk include Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk and other watercourses, from Harrington to Annaside including low lying areas around Whitehaven, Cleator Moor, Egremont, Gosforth, Eskdale and Bootle. We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 06/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels have risen on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent due to recent rainfall. We expect levels to continue to rise until early afternoon today Wednesday 5/10/22, with rainfall forecast to ease through the day. Areas most at risk include Lower Derwent from Bassenthwaite Lake to the coast at Workington, the Cocker from Crummock Water to Cockermouth,  and the River Marron from Ullock to its confluence with the Derwent near Bridgefoot. We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 06/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels have risen steadily on the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwent Water. Further rainfall is expected during today Wednesday 5/10/22 but this is forecast to become less intense through the day. We expect river and lake levels to start to fall overnight tonight. Levels are forecast to continue to fall tomorrow Thursday, with a drier day in prospect. Areas most at risk are the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 06/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Rivers Esk and Irthing due to recent rainfall.
Further rainfall is forecast this morning which may cause river levels to remain high throughout the day.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Esk and Irthing and other watercourses, including low lying areas around Longtown and Brampton.
We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are steadily rising on the Lower River Eden due to rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower River Eden, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe.
Flooding is possible at River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe.
Showers, heavy at times will continue with the River Eden forecast to peak at 9pm this evening, 05/10/2022.
We are monitoring the situation and actively checking rivers for blockages.
Avoid using low lying footpaths or roads that may be affected.  Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow 06/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

River and lake levels continue to rise steadily on the River Greta, River Derwent and Derwent Water due to rainfall. The forecast is for rainfall to ease during the remainder of today which will steady any rise into this evening.  River and Lake levels are due to start receding overnight.   Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, 06/10/2022 or as the situation changes.
